history.content:
EECS Department Tutors Roster

There are many great free group tutoring resources for students taking EE, CS, and EECS courses. However, some students prefer one-on-one interactions. For this reason, the department maintains a roster of folks available for private tutoring. 


If you're interested in adding your name to our tutor list, please fill out this form. You must have received a grade of B or better in the course and taken it at UC Berkeley. By completing the form, you agree to abide by the campus code of conduct and allow us to share listed information. The roster will be available on the EECS Dept website and anyone with a CalNet log in will be able to view it.


The department's role is simply to facilitate an introduction between tutors/tutees. Should someone contact you, you should work to arrange time, location, pay, etc. For reference, the campus's rate for individual tutoring is $15.57/hour. 

We have a new roster each semester. If you were listed in the Fall,  you will need to resubmit. As always, we are especially in need of tutors for upper division courses. 


*****************

Other announcements

  1. Seeking Linux Systems Administrator for Campus Robotics Lab
  2. Free Trip To Dropbox With EOP Stem!
  3. 2019 Women in Engineering Conference
  4. Summer Research Program at MIT
  5. University of Arizona REU Program - CAT Vehicle 2019
  6. Still time to apply for STEM M.Ed. full scholarship
  7. Global Urban Humanities Graduate and Undergraduate Certificate Info Session

 

1. Seeking Linux Systems Administrator for Campus Robotics Lab

UC Berkeley's AUTOLAB which focuses in cutting-edge robotics and uutomation is seeking a qualified and energetic undergrad for a paid part-time position as

Linux Systems Administrator 

 

Job category: Part-time Engineering Aide (work-study status helpful but not required): Approx 2-5 hours per week during academic year, up to 20 hours per

week during summer. Opportunity to work with Prof. Ken Goldberg and 30 post-docs, phds, masters, and undergraduate students as systems admin and

ability to get involved with lab research. 

 

We are looking for someone who is highly reliable, and has experience with some or all of:

  • Required: Proficiency with Linux (installation, configuration, basic scripting)
  • General computer setup and maintenance of programs (Mac OS X, Windows, UNIX)
  • LAMP stack (Linux, Apache, MySQL, PHP)
  • Setting up firewalls
  • Basic networking: IP configuration, SSH, NAT, DNS, DHCP, basic network
  • security
  • Website setup and maintenance (Wordpress)
  • Other experience is a plus (Django, Facebook, etc).

We prefer students who can continue working in the lab for at least one year. Freshman/sophomore standing would be ideal.

 

If interested and qualified, email Prof Ken Goldberg: <goldberg@berkeley.edu> asap with subject line: ** Interested in SYSTEMS ADMIN AUTOLAB and following information in plain text (not .doc or .pdf) and attach your resume: 

1. brief summary of qualifications, experience

2. major,

3. GPA,

4. expected graduation date,

5. relevant courses taken,

6. name and email of one recent supervisor you've worked with,

7. number of hours available per week this term and this summer

  

2. Free Trip To Dropbox With EOP Stem!

Join us on Friday, February 1st for a tour & panel at the Dropbox office in SF! We will be departing from Downtown Berkeley by BART at 10:45am and returning to Berkeley by 3:00 pm. We will be traveling by Bart and EOP STEM will pay for the tickets. The deadline to RSVP is Friday, January 25th! RSVP HERE: tinyurl.com/STEMdropbox19

  

Please note that we will require everyone that attends to sign a wavier. If you have any questions, please feel free to email the EOP STEM Coordinators at: eopstem@gmail.com

 

Please meet at Downtown Bart Station at 10:45am! We hope to see you there!

 

3. 2019 Women in Engineering Conference

Silicon Valley Women in Engineering

Saturday, March 16, 2019, 7:30 AM—7:00 PM at San Jose State University.

$20 early-bird registration ends on 1/11

http://siliconvalleywie.org/

  

4. Summer Research Program at MIT
The MIT Materials Research Laboratory and the Materials Research Science & Engineering Center sponsor a summer research internship program for rising junior and senior undergraduates in the science and engineering fields. This challenging program brings promising students to MIT to learn and perform research in laboratories in a broad selection of materials science subfields. In addition to providing a stipend and round-trip travel expenses, we host presentations and group discussions on topics relevant to materials scientists, such as graduate school, careers in materials science, creating effective poster presentations, and management of intellectual property. At the conclusion of the program, the students present their individual research results at a poster session. The summer research internship, offered each year since 1983, affords students an invaluable experience in top-notch cutting edge research.

 

The summer scholars program is funded by the National Science Foundation REU program (grant number DMR-1419807). MIT is an equal opportunity employer. Women, minorities and persons with disabilities are encouraged to apply. Flyer attached . summer_scholars_2019.pdf

 

5. University of Arizona REU Program - CAT Vehicle 2019

Students will be working on a real autonomous car with technologies dealing with control systems, robotics, cognitive communications, machine learning, software engineering, etc.  Participating students will gain experience in writing academic publications, preparing and giving presentations, and in articulating the story of their compelling research problem and its solution.  Participants will gain experience in applying their research to an actual autonomous vehicle.  For more information: http://catvehicle.arizona.edu/ . Flyer attached 

 

6. Still time to apply for STEM M.Ed. full scholarship

Design a better way for middle or high school students to learn an essential STEM skill or understanding about the world around them. Identify what worked really well in your moments of real learning about STEM, and use your insights to fix what didn’t work.

 

Your learning design could be anything—a video, a physical prototype, a website, an annotated sketch, something else—and take place anywhere. Feel free to show rather than tell—more graphics, fewer words. Above all, create a learning experience for middle or high school students, because a real-life group of students will decide the winner of the competition. Make it hard fun—a little bit hard and a whole lot of fun. The deadline is January 31.

 

If your design wows us, and if you apply to the WW Academy and are eligible for admission, you can win up to a full tuition scholarship ($27,000). This is your chance to hack learning... and launch a new career! More information: https://woodrowacademy.org/scholarship/

 

7. Global Urban Humanities Graduate and Undergraduate Certificate Info Session

The Global Urban Humanities Initiative is hosting Graduate and Undergraduate Certificate info sessions on January 24. We'll share the nuts and bolts of the Certificates.

 

Graduate Certificate Info Session: Jan 24, 10am in 305 Wurster

You can find the application form for the Graduate Certificate here as well as more information about the Graduate Certificate.

Undergraduate Certificate Info Session: Jan 24, 11am in 305 Wurster

You can find the application form for the Undergraduate Certificate here as well as more information about the Undergraduate Certificate.

 

Can't make these info sessions? Email your questions to Program Coordinator Sarah Hwang at sarahhwang@berkeley.edu. 

 


-- 
Nicole McIntyre
Lead EECS Adviser
Department of Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences
205 Cory Hall   |   (510) 642-7372  University of California, Berkeley

Want to schedule an advising appointment? EECS students, click here   |   L&S Students, please use Cal CentralQuick advising question? Try the EECS 101 Piazza or L&S CS Major FAQ
